{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3659565,"name":"wyatt","username":"stormsj28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-21T23:34:51.208Z","cooked":"

looking through higher-level teams CAD and noticing all belts and chains are CADed, our team uses inventor but I’m not sure how I could go about it and or why I should go about it.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-06-21T23:34:51.208Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":406,"readers_count":405,"score":216.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503476,"topic_slug":"cading-belts-and-chains","display_username":"wyatt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3218 CAD"},"post_url":"/t/cading-belts-and-chains/503476/1","custom_user_title":"3218 CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3659570,"name":"Jeremiah Johnson","username":"Johnsonjer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9d8465/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-21T23:38:28.641Z","cooked":"

Modeling belts and chains is really only useful for aesthetic reasons. Intricate belt and chain models can place an unnecessary burden on graphics processing. Only do it if you plan to make detailed images of your robot, and if you do hide or surpress them during normal operation.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-06-21T23:38:28.641Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":405,"readers_count":404,"score":156.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503476,"topic_slug":"cading-belts-and-chains","display_username":"Jeremiah Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61884,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6419M, 648A"},"post_url":"/t/cading-belts-and-chains/503476/2","custom_user_title":"6419M, 648A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3659571,"name":"MetabolicCloth","username":"MetabolicCloth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/metaboliccloth/{size}/9335_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-21T23:38:47.588Z","cooked":"

You model it as a solid body. Draw the profile of the belt and extrude out the width.

okay, would it be usefull for other reasons like intricate path planning or are there other tools to use to make multi pulley loops like triangle pulley loops or tensioners with other pulleys?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-06-21T23:41:25.481Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":371,"readers_count":370,"score":94.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503476,"topic_slug":"cading-belts-and-chains","display_username":"wyatt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":61884,"username":"Johnsonjer","name":"Jeremiah Johnson","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9d8465/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3218 CAD"},"post_url":"/t/cading-belts-and-chains/503476/4","custom_user_title":"3218 CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3659616,"name":"Nick Aarestad","username":"cadandcookies","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cadandcookies/{size}/158154_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T00:18:26.883Z","cooked":"

I would disagree that modeling chain or belt is solely aesthetic-- especially for inexperienced designers, being able to see the path helps for understanding potential issues with interference. Certainly modeling teeth or chain in detail is a bit overkill, but a simple belt volume is extremely useful-- in Onshape, even without featurescripts, all that is is a slot and an offset, provided you know the appropriate dimensions.

In Onshape, there are several featurescripts for modeling chain or belt at various levels of fidelity. I’m not sure what the equivalent workflow, if one exists, in Inventor is, but in Onshape we select the points for a pulley, and twiddle some settings, and that gets us the belt run. In the days before featurescripts, one of the things I remember doing was creating a configurable part that I could then use in assemblies to model the belt.

Best of luck, OP!

If you are using Onshape there are some awesome feature scripts that you can use, some of them are listed here:

frcdesign.org

Featurescripts - FRCDesign.org

A comprehensive learning guide and technical reference for FRC design using Onshape.

stormsj28:

okay, would it be usefull for other reasons like intricate path planning or are there other tools to use to make multi pulley loops like triangle pulley loops or tensioners with other pulleys?

Modeling the path is certainly useful. At work, I create a sketch for the centerline of the belt or chain and leave it at that. You could extrude the general profile along the sketch line to go a little further. There’s no need to model the teeth or links. It’s good practice in the offseason, though.

cadandcookies:

I would disagree that modeling chain or belt is solely aesthetic-- especially for inexperienced designers, being able to see the path helps for understanding potential issues with interference. Certainly modeling teeth or chain in detail is a bit overkill, but a simple belt volume is extremely useful

You are correct. There is no point in modeling the teeth, but a volumetric representation of the belt or chain is useful. It may make directly exporting the BOM with belt or chain length easier.

Johnsonjer:

Modeling belts and chains is really only useful for aesthetic reasons.

We modeled our belts this year in order to make sure we could maximize the elevator height while staying within the 5 meter belt length that we could readily buy and still give ourself an inch or two for tightening/adjusters. (It also made clear to the assembly team how to route the belt, though they’d have figured it out via trial and error eventually, I’m sure.)

In your assembly you should have a design tab in your ribbon, the tab should have a chain button which the little arrow underneath can turn to v-belts or timing belts which you can use to create the belt including weird or unusual paths

If you use inventor, you should definitely use design accelerator. Belts and chains will still only be for visuals, but I find it helpful to have them.

Can you clarify what “design accelerator” is for those not in the know?

Design accelerator is a tab located in an inventor assembly that can be used to model things like gears, belts, springs, etc. It’s labeled “Design” right next to the assemble and 3d model tabs.

I’ll second what others have said about Design Accelerator in Inventor, I use it quite extensively for chain runs (even complicated ones) as it supports both 25 and 35 chain natively and can be useful for checking that you have valid spacing between sprockets and that the chain has clearance. That said, belts I typically just model manually as solids since (at least on my version of Inventor) HTD/GT2 timing belts common to FRC aren’t supported.

If you want to simulate mechanism motions, you can use rotational constraints to create relationships between pulleys/sprockets, but the chain/belt itself will remain static.

Johnsonjer:

It may make directly exporting the BOM with belt or chain length easier.

This is the key reason I like to have simplified belts and chain in CAD. It makes it so much easier for purchasing and assembly.
